questions.text: Which of the following is not a malabsorption syndrome
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) H. pylori infection H. pylori infection is not considered a malabsorption syndrome. Helicobacter pylori is a bacterium that primarily infects the stomach and is associated with conditions such as gastritis, peptic ulcers, and gastric cancer. While it can cause symptoms like nausea, abdominal pain, and bloating, it does not directly lead to malabsorption, which involves an impaired ability of the small intestine to absorb nutrients. H. pylori infection does not affect the absorptive capacity of the small intestine in the way true malabsorption syndromes do. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Whipple’s disease Whipple’s disease is a malabsorption syndrome caused by the bacterium Tropheryma whipplei. This infection leads to the accumulation of macrophages in various tissues, including the small intestine, which interferes with nutrient absorption. Common symptoms of Whipple’s disease include diarrhea, weight loss, and steatorrhea (fatty stools), all indicative of malabsorption. It is a rare but serious condition. B. Coeliac disease Coeliac disease is a well-known malabsorption syndrome. It is an autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to inflammation and damage to the small intestine's lining, specifically the villi. This damage reduces the surface area available for nutrient absorption, leading to symptoms such as chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and malnutrition. C. Tropical sprue Tropical sprue is another malabsorption syndrome that occurs in individuals living in or visiting tropical regions. It is characterized by damage to the small intestine's lining, leading to impaired absorption of nutrients. The exact cause is unclear, but it is believed to be related to an infectious agent. Symptoms include diarrhea, weight loss, and vitamin deficiencies, particularly in folic acid and vitamin B12.

questions.text: Non absorption of fat soluble vitamins is due to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Both Both Celiac sprue and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency can cause malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K). Celiac sprue is an autoimmune disorder in which the ingestion of gluten damages the lining of the small intestine, leading to villous atrophy. This damage reduces the absorptive surface area of the intestine, impairing the absorption of fat and fat-soluble vitamins. As fat is poorly absorbed, so are the fat-soluble vitamins, resulting in deficiencies. Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency occurs when the pancreas fails to secrete sufficient digestive enzymes, which are necessary for the digestion and absorption of fats and fat-soluble vitamins. Conditions like chronic pancreatitis or cystic fibrosis can lead to pancreatic insufficiency, causing malabsorption of not only fats but also fat-soluble vitamins. Therefore, both conditions can result in malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Celiac sprue While Celiac sprue can cause malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins, it alone is not the complete answer. It only addresses one part of the cause for fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies. As discussed above, pancreatic exocrine insufficiency is another significant cause. B. Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency is another condition that can cause malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins, but on its own, it doesn't provide a comprehensive answer to this question. The correct answer requires acknowledging both Celiac sprue and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency. D. None The option "None" is incorrect because both Celiac sprue and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency are known to lead to malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins, making this choice invalid.

questions.text: Abnormal D-xylose test indicates all of the following, Except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pancreatic insufficiency The D-xylose test is used to assess malabsorption by evaluating the absorption of a simple sugar, D-xylose, which is absorbed in the small intestine but does not require pancreatic enzymes for digestion. Therefore, pancreatic insufficiency (which involves a lack of digestive enzymes like amylase and lipase) does not affect the absorption of D-xylose, making it unlikely to cause an abnormal result in this test. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: B. Proximal small intestinal mucosal disease An abnormal D-xylose test indicates proximal small intestinal mucosal disease, such as Celiac disease or tropical sprue, because the absorption of D-xylose primarily occurs in the proximal small intestine. If there is damage to the mucosa in this area, it will impair D-xylose absorption and cause an abnormal test result. This makes the test useful for diagnosing small bowel malabsorption syndromes. C. Bacterial overgrowth syndrome Bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine can also lead to malabsorption of nutrients, including D-xylose. The excessive bacteria can interfere with the absorption process by consuming the nutrients or damaging the small intestine's absorptive surface. Therefore, an abnormal D-xylose test can also indicate bacterial overgrowth syndrome. D. Renal failure In cases of renal failure, D-xylose is excreted by the kidneys. Renal impairment can lead to an abnormal D-xylose test because the excretion process is compromised, potentially resulting in a falsely low level of D-xylose in the urine. Therefore, renal failure can also cause an abnormal D-xylose test.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for investigation of fat malabsorption
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 13C Triclosan 13C Triclosan is not used for the investigation of fat malabsorption. Triclosan is an antibacterial agent commonly used in soaps, toothpaste, and other personal care products, and has no role in assessing fat absorption or malabsorption. The use of 13C-labeled compounds (such as trioctanoin, triolein, and tripalmitin) in diagnostic tests specifically helps evaluate the digestive and absorptive processes of fats in the body, whereas 13C Triclosan is not related to fat metabolism. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. 13C Trioctanoin 13C Trioctanoin is a triglyceride that contains octanoic acid (a medium-chain fatty acid) labeled with 13C. It is used in fat malabsorption testing because it is absorbed directly in the small intestine without the need for bile salts or pancreatic enzymes. The 13C isotope allows the measurement of exhaled CO2 after the absorption of the fat, which helps diagnose malabsorption syndromes. This test is particularly useful for evaluating small bowel function and fat digestion. B. 13C Triolein 13C Triolein is another labeled triglyceride used in fat absorption studies. It contains oleic acid (a long-chain fatty acid) and is absorbed via normal lipase-mediated digestion in the small intestine. After ingestion, the body metabolizes the triolein, and the labeled carbon is exhaled as CO2, which can be measured. This test helps assess fat malabsorption and digestive enzyme efficiency. C. 13C Tripalmitin 13C Tripalmitin is a triglyceride containing palmitic acid (a saturated long-chain fatty acid) and is used in fat malabsorption testing. Similar to the other labeled triglycerides, it undergoes digestion and absorption in the small intestine. The exhalation of 13CO2 after ingestion of this compound is measured to assess digestive and absorptive capacity for fats, making it useful in investigating fat malabsorption syndromes.

Correct Answer (A) Intrinsic factor deficiency The Schilling test is used to evaluate vitamin B12 absorption and is abnormal in cases of intrinsic factor deficiency, which is typically seen in pernicious anemia. The test involves administering vitamin B12 labeled with a radioactive isotope and measuring its excretion in the urine. If intrinsic factor (a glycoprotein produced in the stomach) is deficient, vitamin B12 cannot be properly absorbed in the ileum, leading to reduced urinary excretion of the labeled vitamin. Therefore, a positive Schilling test indicates B12 malabsorption, often due to intrinsic factor deficiency. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: B. Amylase deficiency Amylase deficiency does not affect vitamin B12 absorption and would not lead to an abnormal Schilling test. Amylase is an enzyme that breaks down carbohydrates, and while its deficiency may affect digestion, it does not interfere with vitamin B12 absorption, which is the focus of the Schilling test. C. Lipase deficiency Similarly, lipase deficiency does not impact the absorption of vitamin B12. Lipase is an enzyme responsible for breaking down fats in the digestive system. While lipase deficiency can result in fat malabsorption (leading to symptoms such as steatorrhea), it does not affect the intrinsic factor or the absorption process of vitamin B12, and therefore would not cause an abnormal Schilling test. D. Pancreatic endocrine insufficiency Pancreatic endocrine insufficiency, such as in diabetes or pancreatic insufficiency, typically affects the insulin and glucagon production in the pancreas but does not directly interfere with vitamin B12 absorption. The Schilling test is specifically designed to assess B12 absorption, so issues related to pancreatic endocrine function would not lead to an abnormal result.

choices.text: The schilling test results are abnormal in patients with dietary vitamin B12 deficiency
In patients with pernicious anemia, the results of the schilling test normalize after oral administration of intrinsic factor
In patients with ileal disease the results of the schilling test normalize after oral administration of intrinsic factor.
Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency does not cause schilling test results to be abnormal

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the schilling test for vitamin B12 malabsorption is most accurate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In patients with pernicious anemia, the results of the Schilling test normalize after oral administration of intrinsic factor. The Schilling test is used to assess vitamin B12 absorption and is particularly useful in diagnosing pernicious anemia, a condition in which the body lacks intrinsic factor necessary for vitamin B12 absorption in the ileum. In pernicious anemia, the intrinsic factor is absent, leading to impaired vitamin B12 absorption. When intrinsic factor is administered orally, it can bypass this deficiency, allowing vitamin B12 to be absorbed, thereby normalizing the Schilling test results. This helps to confirm that pernicious anemia is the cause of the vitamin B12 malabsorption. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. The Schilling test results are abnormal in patients with dietary vitamin B12 deficiency. This statement is incorrect. While dietary vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to low serum vitamin B12 levels, it does not typically cause an abnormal Schilling test. The Schilling test specifically assesses how well vitamin B12 is absorbed in the intestines, and in dietary deficiency, the issue is simply insufficient intake of vitamin B12, not malabsorption. Therefore, the Schilling test would generally not be abnormal in patients with dietary deficiency alone. C. In patients with ileal disease, the results of the Schilling test normalize after oral administration of intrinsic factor. This statement is incorrect. In patients with ileal disease, such as Crohn's disease or surgical resection of the ileum, the ileum itself is damaged or missing. Since vitamin B12 absorption primarily occurs in the ileum, the Schilling test would not normalize with oral intrinsic factor, as the problem lies in the ileum, not the intrinsic factor. Even with intrinsic factor, vitamin B12 cannot be absorbed if the ileum is dysfunctional or absent. D. Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency does not cause Schilling test results to be abnormal. This statement is correct in some contexts but is misleading in this case. Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency typically causes malabsorption of fats and fat-soluble vitamins rather than vitamin B12. The Schilling test specifically evaluates vitamin B12 absorption and should be normal in cases of pancreatic insufficiency, since the problem in these cases is with the digestion and absorption of fats, not the absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum. However, in practice, pancreatic insufficiency can sometimes lead to malabsorption of other nutrients that could indirectly affect vitamin B12 absorption, but this is not the primary cause of abnormal Schilling test results.

questions.text: A 12-years-old girl has history of recurrent bulky stools and abdominal pain since 3 years of age. She has moderate pallor and her weight and height are below the 3rd percentile. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to make a specific diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Small intestinal biopsy This child’s symptoms, which include recurrent bulky stools, abdominal pain, moderate pallor, and growth failure (as indicated by weight and height below the 3rd percentile), are suggestive of a malabsorption syndrome. The most common causes of malabsorption in children include celiac disease, tropical sprue, and intestinal infections. The small intestinal biopsy is the most definitive investigation to make a diagnosis of celiac disease, which is the most likely cause in this case. The biopsy allows for the examination of the intestinal mucosa to look for villous atrophy, which is characteristic of celiac disease. This condition is triggered by gluten consumption and can cause growth failure and malabsorption. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: B. Barium studies Barium studies are useful for diagnosing structural abnormalities, such as intestinal obstructions or tumors, but they are not the most appropriate for diagnosing malabsorption syndromes like celiac disease. This patient’s symptoms are more suggestive of a functional issue in nutrient absorption rather than a structural problem. Barium studies would not provide information on the underlying cause of the chronic diarrhea or nutrient malabsorption seen in this case. C. 24-hour fecal fat estimation The 24-hour fecal fat estimation test is useful for diagnosing steatorrhea (excessive fat in the stool), which is a common finding in fat malabsorption syndromes. However, it is not specific for conditions like celiac disease or other small intestinal disorders. This test measures the total amount of fat in the stool, but it does not address the underlying cause of malabsorption, such as intestinal villous damage. Although helpful in supporting the diagnosis of malabsorption, it is not the most definitive test in this case. D. Urinary d-xylose test The urinary d-xylose test is used to assess the absorptive capacity of the small intestine, and it may be helpful in diagnosing malabsorption. However, it is less commonly used nowadays due to advances in more specific diagnostic tests, such as the small intestinal biopsy. The d-xylose test is not as specific as a small intestinal biopsy for diagnosing conditions like celiac disease. It may be abnormal in various malabsorption disorders, but it does not pinpoint the exact cause like a biopsy does.

questions.text: A 30-years-old lady presents with features of malabsorption and iron deficiency anaemia. Duodenal biopsy shows complete villus atrophy. Which of the following antibodies is likely to be present:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Antiendomysial antibodies This 30-year-old woman with malabsorption and iron deficiency anemia, along with a duodenal biopsy showing complete villus atrophy, is presenting with classic features of celiac disease. Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically predisposed individuals. The most common antibody associated with celiac disease is the antiendomysial antibody (EMA). These antibodies are directed against the endomysium, a connective tissue structure surrounding muscle fibers, and their presence strongly correlates with celiac disease. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: B. Anti-goblet cell antibodies Anti-goblet cell antibodies are not typically associated with celiac disease. Goblet cells are responsible for secreting mucus in the intestines, and antibodies against these cells have been observed in some other autoimmune conditions, but they are not a diagnostic feature of celiac disease. Thus, anti-goblet cell antibodies would not be expected in this patient with suspected celiac disease. C. Anti-saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies Anti-saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA) are more commonly associated with Crohn's disease, a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), rather than celiac disease. ASCA is not a marker for celiac disease and would not be expected in this patient with features pointing to celiac disease. D. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are typically associated with vasculitis and some forms of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), especially ulcerative colitis. ANCA is not a marker for celiac disease and would not be expected in a patient with complete villus atrophy due to celiac disease.

choices.text: Increase in thickness of the mucosa
Increase in inflammatory cells in lamina propria

questions.text: The histological features of coeliac disease include all of the following, except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Increase in thickness of the mucosa The histological features of celiac disease primarily include damage to the small intestinal mucosa rather than thickening. In celiac disease, the villi are flattened or atrophic, which causes a loss of mucosal surface area. The mucosal thickness is usually not increased, and this makes option (B) the correct answer. In fact, in celiac disease, you typically see villus atrophy, not an increase in mucosal thickness. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Crypt hyperplasia In celiac disease, there is often crypt hyperplasia. The crypts in the small intestine undergo hyperplasia (increased numbers of cells) as a result of intestinal injury and compensatory hyperproliferation due to the villus atrophy. This is a hallmark finding in celiac disease and is therefore a correct feature. C. Increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes are one of the characteristic findings in celiac disease. The immune response in the small intestine leads to lymphocytic infiltration of the epithelium, particularly CD8+ T lymphocytes. This is a significant histological feature used to diagnose celiac disease. D. Increase in inflammatory cells in lamina propria In celiac disease, there is often an increase in inflammatory cells in the lamina propria, which is the connective tissue layer beneath the epithelial cells of the intestinal mucosa. These inflammatory cells include plasma cells and lymphocytes, and their presence is a key feature of the immune-mediated response in celiac disease.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is uncommon in celiac disease
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Vitamin B12 In celiac disease, the most common deficiencies are fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K), as well as folic acid. However, vitamin B12 deficiency is less common in celiac disease. While vitamin B12 absorption primarily occurs in the ileum, celiac disease usually causes damage to the duodenum and jejunum, which results in malabsorption of nutrients in those areas, but does not directly affect the ileum where B12 absorption occurs. Therefore, vitamin B12 deficiency is uncommon in celiac disease. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Vitamin D Vitamin D deficiency is common in celiac disease due to impaired fat absorption. Since vitamin D is a fat-soluble vitamin, it requires adequate fat absorption to be properly absorbed in the small intestine. In celiac disease, villus atrophy and damage to the mucosa affect fat absorption, leading to vitamin D deficiency in many cases. B. Folic Acid Folic acid deficiency is also common in celiac disease, as malabsorption of folate can occur due to damage to the small intestine. Folic acid is water-soluble and absorbed in the proximal small intestine, which is typically affected in celiac disease. The deficiency of folic acid may lead to megaloblastic anemia. C. Vitamin A Vitamin A deficiency is common in celiac disease for the same reason as vitamin D: it is a fat-soluble vitamin and malabsorption due to villous atrophy in the small intestine leads to poor absorption. Vitamin A deficiency can cause various vision problems and skin changes.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions of malabsorption, an intestinal biopsy is diagnostic-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Whipple’s disease In Whipple's disease, an intestinal biopsy is diagnostic. This disease is caused by Tropheryma whipplei, a type of bacteria, and it leads to malabsorption, diarrhea, weight loss, and other systemic symptoms. The hallmark finding in a biopsy is the presence of foamy macrophages in the lamina propria of the small intestine, which is diagnostic of Whipple’s disease. This finding can be confirmed with PAS (periodic acid-Schiff) staining, which highlights the organisms within the macrophages. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Celiac disease In celiac disease, an intestinal biopsy can be helpful in confirming the diagnosis by showing villus atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and an increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes. However, the diagnosis of celiac disease is usually based on a combination of serological tests (such as anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies) and clinical findings. A biopsy is not always required to make the diagnosis, especially if serologic tests are strongly positive and there is a clear clinical picture. B. Tropical sprue Tropical sprue is a condition that causes malabsorption and diarrhea, typically seen in individuals who have lived in tropical regions. An intestinal biopsy can show villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia, similar to celiac disease, but tropical sprue is usually diagnosed based on clinical history (living in a tropical area), response to treatment (e.g., with antibiotics), and exclusion of other causes. It is not as strongly diagnostic by biopsy alone. D. Lactose intolerance Lactose intolerance is a common cause of malabsorption due to the deficiency of lactase enzyme in the small intestine. It is typically diagnosed with clinical symptoms (such as bloating, diarrhea after consuming dairy) and tests such as the hydrogen breath test or lactose tolerance test, rather than an intestinal biopsy. An intestinal biopsy is not necessary to diagnose lactose intolerance.

questions.text: Most common CNS manifestation of Whipple’s disease is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dementia The most common CNS manifestation of Whipple’s disease is dementia. This disease, caused by Tropheryma whipplei, can affect the central nervous system in many ways. Cognitive impairment, often leading to dementia, is one of the most frequent neurological findings. The dementia in Whipple's disease is usually progressive and can be accompanied by other symptoms like ataxia and seizures. It often presents as subacute or chronic and can be associated with a long-standing infection before the diagnosis is made. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Cerebellar ataxia Cerebellar ataxia can occur in Whipple’s disease but it is less common than dementia. Ataxia, particularly cerebellar, occurs as a result of neurological involvement by the infection, but it is usually accompanied by other manifestations, like dementia, rather than being the most prominent feature. B. Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia Supranuclear ophthalmoplegia is a type of eye movement disorder that can occur in some neurological diseases, including Whipple's disease, but it is much less common than dementia. While ophthalmoplegia can be seen in advanced stages of the disease, it is not the most frequent manifestation of CNS involvement. C. Seizure Seizures can occur in Whipple's disease, as the infection can cause CNS inflammation, but they are typically not the most common manifestation. Seizures in Whipple's disease tend to occur along with other neurological symptoms, and dementia is more commonly the first recognized sign.

questions.text: Which of the following condition causing malabsorption has no effect on villus architecture and no inflammatory reaction?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Giardiasis Giardiasis is a parasitic infection caused by Giardia lamblia, and it is known to cause malabsorption but does not affect villus architecture or cause an inflammatory reaction. The infection can lead to diarrhea, bloating, and fat malabsorption, but the hallmark of giardiasis is the presence of the parasite in the small intestine rather than changes in the villus structure. The gut's mucosal architecture remains largely intact in giardiasis, unlike in other causes of malabsorption. This lack of villous atrophy and inflammation is why giardiasis is the correct answer. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: B. Crohn’s disease Crohn’s disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can cause malabsorption. It leads to significant inflammation in the gut, especially in the small intestine, and is associated with villous atrophy or crypt abscesses. The inflammation is a hallmark of Crohn’s disease, which distinguishes it from giardiasis. Crohn's disease can also affect any part of the digestive tract, leading to structural damage and malabsorption. C. Whipple’s disease Whipple’s disease is caused by Tropheryma whipplei and can lead to malabsorption due to intestinal involvement, but it also causes significant changes in the intestinal architecture, including villus atrophy and inflammatory reactions in the small intestine. This makes it different from giardiasis, which does not cause these changes. D. Celiac Sprue Celiac disease (sprue) is characterized by villus atrophy and inflammatory reactions in the small intestine. The disease is caused by an autoimmune response to gluten, leading to the destruction of the intestinal villi and malabsorption. The immune-mediated inflammation and structural changes in the intestine are characteristic features of celiac disease, making it different from giardiasis, which lacks these effects.

questions.text: Gluten sensitive enteropathy is most strongly associated with: (A1 2003)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HLA-DQ2. Gluten-sensitive enteropathy, more commonly known as celiac disease, is a chronic autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically predisposed individuals. The strongest known genetic association with celiac disease is with specific alleles of the Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) system. Over 95% of individuals with celiac disease express the HLA-DQ2 allele. A smaller percentage of patients, usually those who do not have HLA-DQ2, express the HLA-DQ8 allele. These HLA molecules play a crucial role in presenting gluten peptides to T-cells, initiating the autoimmune response that leads to intestinal damage. The presence of HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 is considered a necessary genetic predisposition for developing celiac disease.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man complaint of 6 month history of weight loss, abdominal distention, bloating, and increased frequency of stools. He has go 6-7 times/day. The stools are oily with foul smell. There is no blood in stools. He also has rashes on trunk with itching. Past history-type 1 diabetes. Skin examination-rashes over trunk present. On Investigations- steatorrhea is present and a small bowel biopsy reveals blunting and flattening of villi. What is the likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Celiac Sprue The most likely diagnosis is celiac sprue (celiac disease), an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten in genetically predisposed individuals. The patient’s symptoms of weight loss, bloating, steatorrhea (oily, foul-smelling stools), and villous blunting on small bowel biopsy are classic findings in celiac disease. The association with type 1 diabetes further supports the diagnosis, as both conditions are linked to autoimmune predisposition. Additionally, the presence of rashes on the trunk with itching strongly suggests dermatitis herpetiformis, a hallmark skin manifestation of celiac disease caused by IgA deposition in the skin. Dermatitis herpetiformis is commonly seen in individuals with gluten sensitivity and resolves with a gluten-free diet. The absence of blood in stools and chronic course also align with celiac disease rather than other gastrointestinal conditions. Why the Other Options are Incorrect: A. Tropical Sprue Tropical sprue is a malabsorption syndrome seen in people living in or traveling to tropical regions. It causes symptoms like diarrhea, weight loss, and steatorrhea. However, it is not associated with dermatitis herpetiformis, type 1 diabetes, or the autoimmune mechanism seen in celiac disease. Additionally, the condition is typically treated with antibiotics like tetracycline and folate supplementation, and small bowel biopsy findings may show blunting of villi but are less specific than in celiac disease. C. Ulcerative Colitis (UC) Ulcerative colitis primarily affects the colon and rectum, causing symptoms like bloody diarrhea, urgency, and tenesmus. It does not cause steatorrhea, villous blunting on biopsy, or dermatitis herpetiformis. The patient’s stool description (oily and foul-smelling, without blood) and the small bowel findings rule out UC. UC is not typically associated with type 1 diabetes or autoimmune skin rashes. D. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) IBS is a functional gastrointestinal disorder that causes abdominal pain, bloating, and changes in bowel habits (diarrhea, constipation, or both). However, IBS does not cause steatorrhea, weight loss, villous atrophy, or dermatitis herpetiformis. Moreover, IBS lacks any associated autoimmune or inflammatory features, which are central to this patient’s presentation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with weight loss and chronic diarrhea. She appears unwell and cachectic. Routine laboratory tests reveal a low hemoglobin level and an increased international normalized ratio (INR) even though she is not taking any anticoagulants. The liver enzymes are normal, but the albumin and calcium levels are low, suggesting generalized malnutrition. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test for malabsorption?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Stool Fat Quantitation The most appropriate initial diagnostic test for malabsorption is stool fat quantitation. This test is used to assess the presence of steatorrhea, which is a hallmark of malabsorption syndromes. The patient's weight loss, chronic diarrhea, low albumin, low calcium, and cachexia suggest a malabsorption disorder, and stool fat quantitation will provide valuable information regarding the fat malabsorption. A high amount of fat in the stool indicates a problem with nutrient absorption, which is consistent with malabsorption syndromes such as celiac disease, pancreatic insufficiency, or chronic gastrointestinal conditions. This test is simple, non-invasive, and gives an immediate clue as to whether fat malabsorption is present, guiding further diagnostic testing. Why the Other Options are Incorrect: A. Xylose Absorption The xylose absorption test is used to assess the absorptive capacity of the small intestine. While it can indicate malabsorption, it is not the first-line test in a patient with suspected malabsorption. Additionally, a normal test may not exclude malabsorption, particularly if fat malabsorption is the primary concern. Stool fat quantitation is more specific for detecting malabsorption of fat, which is commonly associated with generalized malnutrition and weight loss, as seen in this patient. B. Schilling Test The Schilling test is used to assess vitamin B12 absorption and is primarily used for diagnosing pernicious anemia or malabsorption of vitamin B12 due to intrinsic factor deficiency. This test is not appropriate in this case, as the patient’s presentation suggests a more generalized malabsorption, which is likely related to fat or protein absorption, rather than a specific vitamin B12 deficiency. C. X-ray Studies X-ray studies are not helpful in the diagnosis of malabsorption. While imaging studies may be used to rule out structural abnormalities, such as obstruction or disease in the gastrointestinal tract, they do not provide specific information about nutrient absorption. In the case of suspected malabsorption, stool fat quantitation is a much more targeted and effective diagnostic test.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presented with weight loss and chronic diarrhea. Stools are greasy with foul smell. Lab investigations revealed 72 hour stool fat more than 7%. He undergoes diagnostic investigations including small bowel biopsies. The biopsy report reveals normal small bowel mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Post-gastrectomy steatorrhea This patient presents with weight loss, chronic diarrhea, and greasy, foul-smelling stools (steatorrhea), which are classic symptoms of fat malabsorption. The 72-hour stool fat test showing more than 7?t confirms significant fat malabsorption. Despite these findings, the small bowel biopsy is normal, which suggests that the cause of malabsorption is not due to a primary mucosal defect, such as tropical sprue or Whipple's disease. Post-gastrectomy steatorrhea is a known complication following partial gastrectomy or bariatric surgery, which the patient may have undergone in the past. After a gastrectomy, there can be impaired bile acid secretion, which leads to fat malabsorption. The absence of mucosal abnormalities on biopsy fits with this diagnosis, as the cause is more related to altered digestion and absorption rather than a primary small bowel mucosal disorder. Why the Other Options are Incorrect: A. Tropical sprue Tropical sprue is an infectious disease that causes malabsorption and small bowel mucosal changes (such as villous atrophy). However, the biopsy report showing normal small bowel mucosa and no other signs of an infection makes this diagnosis less likely. Tropical sprue would typically show mucosal abnormalities on biopsy. C. Whipple’s disease Whipple’s disease is a rare infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei, which can present with malabsorption, weight loss, diarrhea, and fatigue. However, Whipple’s disease usually causes small bowel mucosal abnormalities, including villous atrophy, macrophages containing PAS-positive granules, and granulomas. The normal small bowel biopsy in this case does not support the diagnosis of Whipple’s disease. D. Abetalipoproteinemia Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare inherited disorder that results in a deficiency of apolipoprotein B, leading to impaired fat absorption and steatorrhea. While this patient presents with steatorrhea, abnormal small bowel biopsy findings (e.g., lipid accumulation within enterocytes) and other characteristic findings (such as retinitis pigmentosa and neurological symptoms) would be expected. The normal small bowel biopsy and the absence of other features make abelipoproteinemia unlikely in this case.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman c/o chronic diarrhea and weight loss. Stools are oily and floats in toilet.On examination pallor is present with ecchymosis seen. Per abdomen is normal with no organomegaly. Blood tests-low Hb with reduced levels of serum ferritin, calcium and folic acid. Malabsorption is suspected. Which of the following investigations is most likely to make a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mucosal biopsy The most appropriate investigation to make a definitive diagnosis in this patient is mucosal biopsy. The patient presents with signs of malabsorption including chronic diarrhea, weight loss, oily stools, and deficiencies in multiple nutrients (e.g., low Hb, reduced ferritin, calcium, and folic acid). A mucosal biopsy is essential to identify the underlying cause of malabsorption, such as celiac disease, tropical sprue, or small bowel lymphoma, among others. Biopsy will reveal changes in the small bowel mucosa, such as villous atrophy or inflammatory infiltration, which are key findings in several malabsorptive conditions. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Presence of fecal osmotic gap The fecal osmotic gap can be useful in distinguishing between osmotic and secretory diarrhea. However, it is not specific enough to diagnose the underlying cause of malabsorption. A high osmotic gap would suggest an osmotic diarrhea (e.g., due to sugars or lactose), while a low gap could suggest a secretory diarrhea (e.g., due to tumors). While the test can help classify diarrhea, it is not definitive in diagnosing the cause of malabsorption. B. D-xylose test The D-xylose test is used to assess the ability of the small intestine to absorb sugars. It can be helpful in evaluating malabsorption caused by diseases such as celiac disease or tropical sprue. However, it is less definitive than a mucosal biopsy in establishing a diagnosis. The D-xylose test may be affected by various factors, including kidney function and motility disorders, and does not provide direct evidence of the underlying pathology in the small bowel. C. Stool fat measurements Stool fat measurements are an important diagnostic tool for evaluating steatorrhea (fatty stools), which is a hallmark of malabsorption. While this test can confirm the presence of fat malabsorption, it does not provide a definitive diagnosis of the underlying cause of malabsorption. It is an initial screening tool, but further testing (such as a mucosal biopsy) is needed to pinpoint the specific condition causing the malabsorption.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman experiences frequent symptoms of heartburn. She reports no weight loss, diarrhea, or dysphagia symptoms. Past medical history is significant for B12 deficiency treated with monthly injections. She appears well, and the examination is normal, except for some patches on her arms where she has lost all the skin pigmentation. Her upper endoscopy is normal, except for gastric biopsies commenting on gastritis. What is likely etiopathogenesis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pernicious anemia The most likely diagnosis in this 57-year-old woman is pernicious anemia. Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disorder that leads to gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency. This patient has a known history of B12 deficiency, which is a hallmark feature of pernicious anemia. The presence of gastritis on her gastric biopsy further supports this diagnosis. Additionally, pernicious anemia is commonly associated with autoimmune gastritis, which can result in autoimmune destruction of gastric parietal cells. These parietal cells are responsible for producing intrinsic factor, which is crucial for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the small intestine. The loss of skin pigmentation (vitiligo) is also consistent with autoimmune conditions, such as pernicious anemia, which often coexists with other autoimmune diseases. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. MALT lymphoma MALT lymphoma (mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma) is a type of cancer often associated with Helicobacter pylori infection. While the patient has gastritis on biopsy, there is no mention of features that would suggest lymphoma, such as the presence of a mass or abnormal lymph nodes. The patient's symptoms of heartburn and gastritis are more consistent with autoimmune gastritis and pernicious anemia rather than lymphoma. C. Chronic pancreatitis Chronic pancreatitis typically presents with epigastric pain, steatorrhea, and diabetes due to loss of pancreatic function. The patient’s symptoms of heartburn and gastritis are not typical of chronic pancreatitis. Additionally, chronic pancreatitis is not typically associated with B12 deficiency or autoimmune gastritis, making this diagnosis unlikely in this case. D. Helicobacter pylori infection While Helicobacter pylori infection is a common cause of gastritis and peptic ulcers, the patient’s history of B12 deficiency and the skin pigmentation loss (vitiligo) are more indicative of pernicious anemia than an H. pylori infection. H. pylori typically causes chronic superficial gastritis and may contribute to peptic ulcer disease, but it is not associated with B12 deficiency or vitiligo, which are more characteristic of pernicious anemia.
